text: and now a guide to the UK general
election and how a government has formed
phenom Brits
fear not British elections aren't as
complicated as the rules of cricket but
there are one or two basics most
importantly it's a constituency based
system our constituency being a
geographical area containing about
60,000 voters the entire country has
sliced up into six hundred and fifty of
them which each collect their own MP so
basically the party which gets the most
MPs wins MPs are elected under the
first-past-the-post system no it doesn't
involve tenting candidates dashing past
a bit of wood it just means you got more
votes than any other person but not
necessarily a majority of the votes cast
pretty much anyone can stand as an MP as
long as they're over 18 and either
British Irish or a Commonwealth citizen
and not an aristocrat mad or in prison
the other striking thing is that British
elections are mercifully short by law
they only last 25 days take that America
as to the outcome of the election
normally one of the two main parties
wins a majority and their leader becomes
Prime Minister end of story
but as in 2010 we could end up with a
hung parliament though worry there are
no gallows
it just means no party one 326 seats or
more finally to the crowning moment
excuse the plan of the British electoral
system the government doesn't just
happen after the election the Queen has
to invite someone to become Prime
Minister and form one she doesn't vote
and she doesn't really choose it it's
not called the Magisters government for
nothing
